steps.text: Holy 💩 you nailed it! Or maybe you’ve heard about this, huh? Or maybe you are just a big Michael Jordan 🏀 fan… But still, it can be hard to believe it actually happens, right?

The chance that two people in the same room have the same birthday — that is the Birthday Paradox 🎉. And according to fancy math, there is a 50.7% chance when there are just 23 people* in a room. This is in a hypothetical world. In reality, you people aren’t born evenly throughout the year and it doesn’t count leap years, but the numbers are still pretty accurate.It may sound crazy, but like a lot of crazy things, it is simpler than it appears. And that is why it’s so cool.

Of course I can make you believe it. But we won’t look at formulas 🤓 or simulations 🤖, let’s invite the last 21 real people like you who just visited this site to our virtual party. 🎈= shared birthday

💥 Boom! I told you it could happen.🥚Aww we laid a goose egg. But that is just one instance, and it would be wrong of me to stop there. Because each time we get 23 people together, it’s basically a coin flip that we get a shared birthday. The more we repeat this, the more balanced our results will be. That is the Law of Large Numbers in action.

Okay, let’s bring in 19 more groups of 23 people and see what happens. I have a good feeling we will experience the magic of the paradox a few times 🤞. Hmm let’s speed this up. A little more... A lot more...

As you can see, we are converging on that 50.7% success rate. But wait, there’s more! Let’s boost this sample size to include everyone who has ever visited this site. We will put it on warpspeed ⚡️so we aren’t here all day.
